item.content:encoded:
Quick unformatted infodump: "Because of the way death chance, max push, and drain levels/range work, seasons 3 and 4 are actually easier for phase fighting than season 6, and the worst season for phase fighting is 8.

That being said, the difference between seasons is more about strategy than difficulty. At higher seasons you can win easily just by having high drain levels and at lower seasons it's more about knowing what items to get for the bonuses. Even being season 8 isn't that much of a hindrance. Really, the worst part about low season r00t is grinding core for recompiling, and you're almost at the point where even that isn't very difficult.

You're over thinking this. Grab the Drain and Edge bonuses from purchase r00t powers, drink some juice, play 10 scratchy tickets, do 4-6 hacks, summon the twilight guardian, spend 30k mahjong xp on zawa zawa, switch to the Detective Duo team, grab the 555 Phone, then go crush The One Sin three times, draining it the last time. Yes, I mean in the same day, it's really not that hard."

Taltamir, I think forfeiting costs you an amount of stamina equal to half the phase's original HP. This is separate from the risk. I've only tested this on 0-days-old phases so far, but it seems to make sense.

For phases with tons of HP, especially ones that you're shooting the core on, it's better to fight them till you die naturally instead of forfeiting.

item.content:encoded:
I just forfeited a fight against the 11 tails revenge (28 days alive, I was speed looping) and got a corruption of 750 stamina.
Then (festival day) I summoned it again, beat it, drained it, and got 550 corruption.

I corrected it to 750 risk after forfeiting the fight but it seems that was a mistake. I think one of two rules are in place here:
A. Risk increases over time (50 a week maybe?)
B. Forfeiting costs a set amount of extra risk.

Also, potentially this is limited to the 11 tails revenge.
It would be great if other people can run some experiments too and confirm which of those rules is true (or maybe even different rules altogether) and make the necessary corrections to this page.
